**Daoist Canon Treatise**

**Title:** *Daoist Canon Treatise* (*Daodian Lun*). Four scrolls. Author unknown.
**Source Text:** *Daoist Canon of the Zhengtong Era*, Taiping Section.
**Collated Versions:** Dunhuang manuscripts: 1. S.3547; 2. P.2920 (hereafter referred to as "Dunhuang versions").

**Daoist Canon Treatise, Scroll One**
The Supreme Lord

The Purple Void Three Primordials Purple Essence Lord,¹ whose form spans ninety million *zhang*. In the three months of spring, his head bears the Nine Primordials Flying Dawn Tassel Crown, he wears a cinnabar brocade flying skirt, and is girded with the Nine Heavens Dragon-Script Tiger Talisman. At his waist hangs the Sun Essence Life-Extending Sword, and his feet stand upon a five-colored lotus. His head radiates the light of the Seven Treasures.² In the three months of summer, he transforms into a youth with cloud-tousled topknots, clad in five-colored robes, holding a flowered banner. His radiance blazes brilliantly, illuminating the Highest Clarity. In the three months of autumn, he transforms into a dragon-headed, serpent-bodied form, azure and yellow resplendent, his light illuminating the Jade Void. In the three months of winter, he transforms into a tri-colored light of purple, azure, and white, dim and luminous like the moon’s glow.

The True Yang Primordial Elder Mysterious Unity Lord, whose form spans fifty million *zhang*. In the three months of summer, his head bears the Treasure Dawn Permeating Essence Jade Crown,⁵ he wears a nine-colored cloud-patterned brocade robe, and is girded with the Supreme Lord’s Mandate Spirit Seal and Dragon Radiance Cinnabar Script. He constantly stands upon purple clouds, and when seated, rests upon a seven-colored lotus. His radiance blazes brilliantly.⁶ In the three months of autumn, he transforms into an infant seated within the Purple Void, his head crowned with a five-colored flowered canopy, holding a five-fungus flowered banner. In the three months of winter, he transforms into moonlight, azure and luxuriant, within the purple clouds and above the azure blossoms. His radiance flows and illuminates, penetrating the Highest Clarity. In the three months of spring, he transforms into a tri-colored light of azure, green, and dark, interwoven in chaos like intertwining clouds, surging within the Highest Clarity.

The Supreme Micro Heavenly Emperor Lord, whose form spans thirty million *zhang*. In the three months of autumn, his head bears the Nine Primordials Flying Tassel Crown,⁷ he wears a seven-colored phoenix-cloud robe, and is girded with the Night Radiance Treasure Seal and Intertwining Spirit Silk Sash.⁸ He constantly stands upon a five-colored lion, his body emanating thirty-two hues of precious light, above the Highest Clarity. In the three months of winter, he transforms into boundless Perfected Immortals,⁹ his body suffused with golden light, illuminating the ten directions. He stands upon a nine-colored blossom, holding a golden bell. In the three months of spring, he transforms into sunlight, purple rays blazing brilliantly above the Jade Void, illuminating the ten directions. In the three months of summer, he transforms into a tri-colored light of white, azure, and green, intertwining like layered petals.

The Azure Spirit Yang Peace Lord, whose form spans fifty million *zhang*. In the three months of winter, his head bears the Three Essences Hibiscus Dawn Crown, he wears a cloud-patterned cinnabar brocade flying robe, and his feet tread upon a nine-colored lion. He is girded with flowing gold fire bells and the Seven Primordials sash. His body emanates sevenfold-transforming light, resplendent above the Jade Clarity. In the three months of spring, he transforms into an elder with a flying dragon upon his head, his mouth holding the moon, clad in feathered robes, and holding a purple sash. He stands upon cinnabar clouds, illuminating the Jade Clarity. In the three months of summer, he transforms into a tiger-headed, human-bodied form, five-colored and variegated, his light illuminating the ten directions. In the three months of autumn, he transforms into a tri-colored light of yellow, green, and purple, chaotic within the Highest Clarity, like the sun’s halo.

The Highest Primordial Supreme Three Primordials Lord, whose form spans thirty million *zhang*.¹⁰ In the three months of spring, his head bears the Treasure Mystery Supporting Dawn Feather Crown,¹¹ he wears a purple *qi* floating cloud brocade cloak and a nine-colored dragon brocade feathered skirt. At his waist hang flowing gold fire bells, tiger talismans, and dragon scripts.¹² He sits within the Great Void,¹³ beneath his knees ever-present clouds of cinnabar, green, and azure, their radiance blazing brilliantly, illuminating the ten directions of the Mysterious. In the three months of summer, he transforms into a single body with three heads, wearing a seven-tiered treasure crown and clad in a three-pure flying cloud brocade robe. He stands upon a nine-colored phoenix, illuminating the ten directions. In the three months of autumn, he transforms into the Seven Luminaries, their flowery essence and jade light blazing upon purple clouds,¹⁴ their luminous hues luxuriant like the sun’s glow. In the three months of winter, he transforms into a tri-colored light of azure, purple, and white, dense and surging like golden essence.

The Highest Supreme Primordial Lord, whose form spans thirty million *zhang*. In the three months of summer, his head bears the Purple Primordial Treasure Crown, he wears a cinnabar brocade seven-colored robe, and is girded with the Vast Falling Seven Luminaries Primordial Seal. At his waist hangs the Three Treasures Summoning Immortals’ Staff. He constantly stands upon a five-colored lotus, his radiance blazing brilliantly. In the three months of autumn, he transforms into a dragon-headed, human-bodied form, five-colored and variegated, his radiance flowing and illuminating the ten directions. In the three months of winter, he transforms into a three-eyed spirit,¹⁵ his light dim and luminous, illuminating the Highest Clarity. In the three months of spring, he transforms into a dual-colored light of azure and white,¹⁶ resplendent within the Primordial *Qi*, above the Purple Empyrean.

The Highest Clarity Purple Essence Three Purities Lord, whose form spans seventy million *zhang*. In the three months of autumn, his head bears the Permeating Essence Dawn Crown, he wears a five-colored variegated tiger robe, and is girded with the Intertwining Spirit Silk Sash and the Summoning Immortals’ Sword. He constantly stands upon a nine-colored lion,¹⁷ his neck emanating a halo of light illuminating the Highest Clarity. In the three months of winter, he transforms into a phoenix-headed, human-bodied form, clad in azure, green, and purple feathered robes, his radiance flowing and blazing within the Highest Clarity. In the three months of spring, he transforms into a human-headed, dragon-bodied form, his patterns resplendent and illuminating the Highest Clarity. In the three months of summer, he transforms into a dual-colored light of black and yellow, chaotic and intertwining like ascending clouds.

The August Clarity Cavern Perfected Lord, whose form spans fifty million *zhang*. In the three months of winter, his head bears the Three-Ridge Jade Dawn Crown, he wears a seven-colored tiger-patterned robe,¹⁸ and is girded with flowing gold fire bells and a seven-colored staff banner. He constantly stands upon three-pure flying clouds, his radiance blazing resplendently within the Jade Void. In the three months of spring, he transforms, his head bearing a yellow kerchief, clad in a thirty-two-striped ritual robe, holding a flowered banner, standing upon purple clouds.

In the three months of summer, he transforms, closing his eyes in inner vision, his head bearing a flowered canopy, his feet standing upon a lotus blossom. In the three months of autumn, he transforms into a dual-colored light of yellow and white, its luminous flow resplendent within the Great Void, illuminating the Ten Heavens.

The August Four Elders Dao Lord, whose form spans seventy million *zhang*. In the three months of spring, his head bears the Primordial Perfected Seven-Treasured Jade Crown, he wears a phoenix-patterned robe, is girded with *huoluo* flowing bells, and carries the Summoning Perfected talisman. He constantly stands upon a nine-colored lion, surrounded by twelve flowered lights, above the Highest Clarity. In the three months of summer, he transforms into a child, clad in five-colored robes, his mouth holding the Seven Stars, standing upon white clouds. In the three months of autumn, he transforms into a human-headed serpent-bodied form, five-colored and resplendent above the Jade Void. In the three months of winter, he transforms into a tri-colored cloud of blue, red, and white, intertwining and coiling within the Dark Void.

The Jade Dawn Supreme Great Dao Lord, whose form spans ninety million *zhang*. In the three months of autumn, his head bears the Hundred-Transformations Divine Light Jade Crown, he wears a robe of flying frost pearls and a seven-colored tiger-patterned garment, is girded with the Nine-Colored *Liluo* Seal, and carries Morning Light and Moon Bright bells. He constantly sits upon seven-colored clouds, his radiance flowing resplendently within the Highest Clarity. In the three months of winter, he transforms, his head bearing a seven-rayed circular wheel, his body clad in a thirty-two-colored ritual robe, his feet standing upon a nine-colored lion, his radiance blazing brilliantly above the Highest Clarity, within the Supreme Tenuity. In the three months of spring, he transforms into Lord Lao, his head bearing a horned kerchief, his body clad in a tiger-patterned robe, holding a golden talisman, standing upon five-blossomed *zhi* mushrooms. In the three months of summer, he transforms into a dual-colored light of purple and yellow, its radiance luminous and intertwining within the Purple Void.

The Central Yellow Elder Lord, whose form spans thirty million *zhang*. In the three months of summer, his head bears the Treasured Coral Morning Crown, he wears a nine-colored cloud-patterned robe, and is girded with the Intertwining Numinous Purple Sash, surrounded by twelve flowered lights. He constantly stands upon a five-colored lion, his radiance flowing resplendently within the Highest Clarity. In the three months of autumn, he transforms into a jade lad, his head bearing a Seven Essences flowered crown, clad in a flying celestial feathered robe, holding a flowered banner. In the three months of winter, he transforms into a perfected immortal, his entire body the color of yellow gold, clad in seven-colored robes, his neck bearing a circular wheel, his feet treading upon a lotus blossom, his radiance flowing brilliantly. In the three months of spring, he transforms into a tri-colored light of purple, green, and blue, intertwining above the Jade Void.

The Supreme Ultimate Boundless Dao Lord, whose form spans thirty million *zhang*. In the three months of autumn, his head bears the Morning Tassel Treasure Crown, he wears a seamless nine-colored patterned robe, is girded with the Divine Tiger Supreme Talisman and the Treasured Immortal Sword, his neck bearing flowing golden light, illuminating the seventy-four directions. He constantly stands upon a dark turtle. In the three months of winter, he transforms into a tiger-headed dragon-bodied form, five-colored and resplendent, brightly illuminating the Highest Clarity. In the three months of spring, he transforms into Lord Lao, his hair hanging loose to his waist, clad in a flying blue feathered robe, standing upon purple clouds. In the three months of summer, he transforms into a dual-colored light of red and blue, intertwining above the Purple Void.

The Supreme Clarity Great Dao Lord, whose form spans ninety million *zhang*. In the three months of winter, his head bears the Nine Primordials Penetrating Heaven Crown, he wears a nine-colored dragon robe, is girded with the Three *Qi* Central Seal and the Intertwining Numinous White Sash, his feet standing upon three-pure clouds, his radiance resplendent above the Highest Clarity. In the three months of spring, he transforms into a three-headed phoenix, its mouth holding a white sash, its body bearing nine-colored feathers, its patterns resplendent and brilliantly illuminating the Highest Clarity. In the three months of summer, he transforms into a tri-colored circular light, its hue purely red like a chariot’s wheel, its radiance brightly illuminating above the Supreme Clarity. In the three months of autumn, he transforms into a tri-colored light of purple, white, and yellow, its radiance resplendent and brilliantly illuminating the Highest Clarity.

The August Primordial Purple Origin Lord, whose form spans ninety million *zhang*. In the three months of spring, his head bears the Purple Origin Treasured Coral Divine Crown, he wears a three-colored tiger-patterned robe, is girded with the White Numinous Sash, his feet standing upon three-pure clouds, his radiance shining brilliantly, penetratingly observing the ten directions above the Highest Clarity, within the Eight Tenuities. In the three months of summer, he transforms into a perfected immortal, his entire body golden, his neck bearing a circular wheel, his patterns resplendent, his radiance luminous, illuminating the ten directions. In the three months of autumn, he transforms into a tri-colored lad, clad in five-colored robes, holding a flowered banner, his radiance resplendent and brilliantly illuminating the Highest Clarity. In the three months of winter, he transforms into a tri-colored light of dark green, azure, and purple, its radiance brilliantly illuminating the Highest Clarity.

The Peerless Central Perfected Supreme Elder Lord, whose form spans seventy million *zhang*. In the three months of summer, his head bears the Penetrating Heaven Treasure Crown, he wears a seven-colored mottled robe, is girded with the Numinous Flying Purple Sash and the Penetrating Perfected Sword, standing upon a nine-colored lion, his radiance penetratingly illuminating, resplendent above the Highest Clarity. In the three months of autumn, he transforms into an old man, his head bearing a yellow kerchief, clad in a yellow-black robe, holding a golden staff, standing upon a lotus blossom, his radiance illuminating the ten directions. In the three months of winter, he transforms into the light of three suns, its radiance luminous, illuminating the Ten Heavens, the three *qi* blending together like an egg yolk. In the three months of spring, he transforms into a tri-colored light of purple, dark green, and white, its radiance resplendent, penetratingly illuminating the Nine Heavens.

The *Scripture of the Nine Perfected* states: The Central Yellow Elder Lord is a disciple of the Supreme August Emperor of the Supreme Tenuity Heaven.

In the second year of the Qingxu Shanghuang era, amidst primordial chaos, he first came into being. The sun’s radiance doubled in splendor, its light interwoven with the numinous. Five-colored clouds formed a canopy, while auspicious mist and mysterious haze settled in stillness.

At the age of seven, he naturally grasped the essentials of longevity and the methods of celestial transcendence. With profound contemplation, he reverently embraced the mysterious and true, his spirit wandering in solitude, his heart dwelling in the wellspring of the divine. He widely embodied the eight absolutes, grasped emptiness and cast forth gold, freed himself from the nets of ornate entanglement, and roamed unbound through the marketplace of the void. His eyes opened the gate of the mysterious origin, his hands parted the halls of the myriad chambers. Thus, the celestial melody exquisitely resounded, and karmic resonance with the mysterious arose.

Thereupon, the Supreme August One bestowed upon him the *Scripture of the Nine Perfected* of the Emperor Lord and the secret chapters of the Eight Dao. Through cultivation, he achieved the Dao and received the scriptures, becoming the Perfected of the Great Ultimate.

The *Scripture of the Golden Root in Purple Script* states: The Azure Essence Emperor Lord is a disciple of the Nine Yang Primordial Jade Emperor. In the first year of the Zhonghuang era, in the year corresponding to the Eastern Pivot of Heaven, he first announced his radiance to the Lord of Light and was nurtured in the Jasper Forest of the Seven Treasures beneath the boundless Heaven of the Jade Mound in the Jade Land of the Mystic Mound. At the edge of the ninefold domains, his dharma-transformations aligned with the celestial patterns. For three dawns, the morning light broke forth. Nine dragons flanked his side, while seven-colored jasper phoenixes shaded his body. Divine unicorns and sacred mushrooms emitted mysterious radiance, celestial maidens exhaled essence to nourish his perfection, jade lads cast flowers to dispel impurity, and divine consorts scattered incense to repel dust.

He practiced fetal breathing and natural refinement. At the age of twelve, his face shone with a golden countenance, his body bore sacred talismans, his words chimed like golden ornaments, and seventy-two hues luminously reflected his jade form. For three mornings, the celestial net enveloped him; the six *qi* turned in unison. A mysterious canopy of purple spirit arose from his chamber, and the flowing essence of light illuminated his courtyard. Alone, he embodied the perfected and flourished, his spirit harmonious and his demeanor orderly, following the transformations of the cosmos, rising and sinking with its currents. His heart dwelled in the realm of luminous rosy clouds, and he roamed the jade precincts of the Jade Land. Wielding the staff of the Primordial August One, he traversed the ninefold domains and the mounds of the setting sun, carefree and gazing afar.

After countless kalpas, he returned to the cloud chambers of the pure retreat. There, purple clouds formed his dwelling, rosy clouds his city, yellow gold his palace, and white jade his couch. The five *qi* intertwined, his terrace rose in layered heights, jade steps adorned with patterns, phoenix towers facing the four directions. Golden lads attended his side, jade maidens held his towels. Over five thousand celestial transcendents arrayed as guards, celestial beasts in formation, feathered riders like scales, dragons and tigers warding off evil, paired and crouching in symmetry. The ninefold convergence of mysterious *qi*, the divine wind stirring the mist, fragrant incense wafting ceaselessly through the jasper palace, flowing essence and jade light penetratingly illuminating the Eight Heavens.

Azure Essence is an alternate name of the Purple Clarity Emperor Lord. He received the Purple Script’s wondrous formulas from the Primordial Jade Emperor—all essential secrets of the myriad scriptures, celestial writings of the Nine Heavens, and hidden texts of the Eight Assemblies.

The Jade Emperor commanded the Highest Direct Perfected, the General Lord of Transcendents, to compile and edit the precious catalog, gathering them into the *Scripture of Collective Praise*. With purple brush, he transcribed the texts, inscribing them on golden tablets—all derived from the Way of the Primordial Sovereign of Antiquity, composed by the loftiest sages, compiled into scrolls, and transmitted to the Azure Essence Emperor Lord.

The *Scripture of Purple Radiance and Blazing Light* states: The Emperor Lord of the Supreme Tenuity Heaven was born at the inception of the Primordial Azure, an heir of the numinous radiance. At the very beginning when the mysterious *qi* had yet to coalesce, he took form as the lineage of flowing fragrance. His light interwove with the numinous, purple clouds blazed like lightning, mysterious mist enveloped the sky, and cinnabar radiance entwined him. Subtle awakening arose in concealment. He gathered and embraced the supreme harmony, unfolding the pure and harmonious. Exhaling and inhaling the dark abyss, he descended into the womb of emptiness and birth, nourished by the curved mushrooms of the vast spring. At the inception of his form, he studied the Way of summoning the perfected. With distant thoughts and far-reaching vision, he inwardly contemplated, sitting in observation of the boundless, profoundly preserving the hidden and void.

At the age of three, he rectified the center and aligned with correctness. His true spirit became luminous, and he foresaw what had not yet come to pass. He thoroughly examined the farthest reaches of the celestial realms—no hidden place was not discerned, no height was not seen, no depth was not peered into.

At the age of fourteen, his golden countenance inwardly shone, and jade splendor outwardly reflected. His wisdom was penetrating, his spirit keen. He bore the title of Emperor of the Lateral Hall, his duty to purify the rosy clouds of the Nine Empyreans and gaze afar upon the source of the Clarity of the Void. He illuminated the mechanisms of the utmost mystery, governed and synthesized the currents of the myriad streams. Accumulated resonance added to the hidden convergence, and wondrous resonance arose naturally. Thus, he received the title of Supreme Emperor, the accumulation of resonance bestowed upon him—not merely granted by birth.

The *Scripture of the Three Flowers’ Precious Radiance and Inner Circle* states: The Southern Culmen, General Controller of the Registers, Supreme Perfected Lord of Prohibitions, in the first year of the Shihuang era, the year corresponding to *renwu*, on the seventh day of the seventh month at midday, in the Jasper Forest beneath the Seven Treasures of the Boundless Longevity Heaven’s Jade Land, the Phoenix Capital’s Purple Terrace, bowed his head at the Jade Pavilion and inquired of the Jade Emperor, the Heavenly Worthy of the Primordial Void: Though the celestial heir and imperial foundation have had their names inscribed in the imperial records and have ascended to the highest office, overseeing the myriad transcendents, they have yet to receive the methods of bestowing the mandate of salvation. I wish to be granted the precious formulas to save later worthies.

Thereupon, the Heavenly Worthy of the Primordial Void addressed the Southern Culmen, General Controller, Supreme Perfected Lord of Prohibitions: The formulas for extending life and reversing years in the Golden Chamber are secretly preserved in the Nine Heavens above, in the Palace of Great Existence, the Ninefold Chamber of the Golden Terrace and Jade Hall. This Way is profoundly subtle; it is not something that median perfected ones can participate in or practice. This method shares the same root as the nine *qi* and equals the radiance of the Three Luminaries. Heaven and Earth endure forever. If cultivated ten thousand times, one’s rank will be elevated to that of an immortal minister. Riding the mist and driving the void, one will ascend to the imperial throne. I now reveal this to you—follow and practice it.

The *Scripture of the Jade Emperor’s Genealogy of the Primordial August One* fully lists the eight hundred Dao Lords by name and title, which are not recorded here.

The Great Spirit:
The *Canon of the Supreme Perfected* of the Supreme August One states: The Great Void, the Great Primordial—without beginning, without origin—contains a Great Spirit, formless yet existent, possessing wisdom and numinosity. His numinous wisdom and understanding penetratingly illuminate all beings. When beings have resonance, the Great Spirit descends in response, responding as the master of resonance. He is called the Great Spirit.

The *Scripture of Laozi’s Admonitions* states: The divine person embodies the Dao and penetrates the numinous, transforming and responding to causes. Without form yet taking form, now vanishing, now abiding—dispersed, they become qi; gathered, they become human. They come and go without gate, enter and exit without gap, ascending to heaven and descending to earth, operating within the Six Directions. Where the Dao resides, they manifest as human omens; without being summoned, they arrive; without being called, they respond. They bestow mysterious merit and profound transformations in secret, their name beyond naming—thus they are called the divine person.

The *Supreme Wondrous Scripture of the Numinous Treasure’s Limitless Salvation of Humanity* states: Within it is the divine being who saves people from death; within it is the Controller of Horses, the great divine being who saves the world; within it is the Venerable Divine Being of the Southern Heights who saves from calamity; the boundless great divine beings who grant immortality and save the world.

**Flying Immortals**
The *Scripture of Illuminating Perfection* states: The Heavenly Worthy then commanded the summoning of the flying immortals and divine persons of the ten directions. They opened the repository of the Long Night, the Nine Dark Jade Caskets, and brought forth the *Illuminating Perfection’s Codes and Precepts* to save the youths.

The *Supreme Wondrous Scripture of the Numinous Treasure’s Limitless Salvation of Humanity* states: Today, the records of all heavens are examined beneath the imperial canopy. "Today" here collectively refers to the mornings of the Three Origins and Eight Festivals’ fasting vigils, when the flying immortals of the ten directions and all great sages assemble at Jade Capital to review and determine the registers. On that day, the Heavenly Worthy celebrates with a grand audience beneath the canopy.

The **Eastern Limitless Flying Immortal Divine King, Great Sage of Eternal Life**, boundlessly saves humanity.
The **Southern Limitless Flying Immortal Divine King, Great Sage of Eternal Life**, boundlessly saves humanity.
The **Western Limitless Flying Immortal Divine King, Great Sage of Eternal Life**, boundlessly saves humanity.
The **Northern Limitless Flying Immortal Divine King, Great Sage of Eternal Life**, boundlessly saves humanity.
The **Northeastern Limitless Flying Immortal Divine King, Great Sage of Eternal Life**, boundlessly saves humanity.
The **Southeastern Limitless Flying Immortal Divine King, Great Sage of Eternal Life**, boundlessly saves humanity.
The **Southwestern Limitless Flying Immortal Divine King, Great Sage of Eternal Life**, boundlessly saves humanity.
The **Northwestern Limitless Flying Immortal Divine King, Great Sage of Eternal Life**, boundlessly saves humanity.
The **Upper Limitless Flying Immortal Divine King, Great Sage of Eternal Life**, boundlessly saves humanity.
The **Lower Limitless Flying Immortal Divine King, Great Sage of Eternal Life**, boundlessly saves humanity.
The **Perfected Flying Immortal Divine Kings of the Ten Directions, Great Sages of Eternal Life who boundlessly save the world**, all ride flying clouds, crimson chariots, and green carriages, with a hundred million chariots and ten thousand riders, arriving through the void.

**Youths**
The *Scripture of the Five Refinements of the Numinous Treasure to Revive the Corpse* states: At that time, the Heavenly Worthy was in the Fragrant Grove Garden of the Abode of Eternal Joy, teaching and transforming seven thousand two hundred and forty youths. When the Dharma matters were roughly complete, the most wise youths addressed the Heavenly Worthy: "Now that all has been opened and renewed, the August Dao flows freely, and its blessings extend to the ten directions. We humbly beseech the Heavenly Worthy to continue bestowing great compassion and fulfill the August Grace."

Thereupon, the Heavenly Worthy universally commanded the Celestial Emperors of all heavens to open the Dharma gates anew for the most wise youths.

The *Scripture of the Purple Radiance of Blazing Light* states:
The **Eastern Azure Radiance Youth**, named Azure Supreme Jade, styled Flying Upright, his body the color of blue-green mist, his flowing light shining brilliantly.
The **Southern Crimson Radiance Youth**, named Cinnabar Splendor, styled Mysterious Record, his body the color of red mist, his flowing light mirroring the southern direction.
The **Western White Radiance Youth**, named Vast Splendor, styled Returning Spirit Child, his body the color of white mist, his flowing light shining brilliantly.
The **Northern Black Radiance Youth**, named Mysterious Brightness Supreme, styled Supreme Yin Script, his body the color of black mist, his flowing light penetratingly illuminating the northern direction.
The **Central Yellow Radiance Youth**, named Upholding Loyalty, styled Yellow Register Child, his body the color of yellow mist, like the essence of yellow gold, his flowing light resplendent.

The *Scripture of Supreme Wisdom* praises:
Golden flowers hold the *Cavern Scripture*,
Fragrant incense is borne by all immortal youths.
Their whistling songs resound through the Mysterious Capital,
Jade chimes strike the jasper bells.

The *Scripture of Ascending to the Mystery* states: The **Golden Radiance Youth**.

*(Descriptions of attire and appearance follow.)*

The *Scripture of the Arrayed Records of the Three Heavenly Lords of Highest Clarity* states: The **Lesser Wild Youth**.

*(Descriptions of terrestrial and mountain ranks follow.)*

The *Perfect Scripture of the Great Cavern* states: The **Primordial Origin Youth**.

*(Descriptions of terrestrial, mountain, and cavern ranks follow.)*

**Great Beings**
The *Scripture of Ascending to the Mystery* states: The Most High said: "Dao-ling, you may exchange greetings with this Great Being." This Great Being is named Excellent Victory. Having long cultivated pure practices, his merits and accomplishments are complete, no different from yours.

The *Scripture of the Supreme Perfected’s Codes* states: Those of the Lesser Vehicle who study perilous demonic disturbances are not saved but remain bound to the Six Heavens. Thus, the Great Being arouses the mind toward the Supreme Vehicle, where merits are lofty and virtue weighty, and demons cannot corrupt. Though they come to harass, all immediately submit and surrender. Having surrendered and received their duties, they transform their bodies into the real. If they cannot transform instantly, they remain among the demonic hosts, who recommend and protect them, assisting the students to ascend to the Mystery.

The *Scripture of the Supreme Numinous Writ of the Jade Pivot* states: The Great Being of the Supreme Vehicle boundlessly saves and delivers. Delving into the ultimate Dao, penetrating the source of wisdom, unwavering from beginning to end, their person suffices to save beings. They attain transcendence and unite with the treasure.

The first fascicle of the *Discourses on Daoist Canons* concludes.

*(Dunhuang manuscript variant: "void" as "numinous." Additionally, the Dunhuang manuscript includes preceding text: "...moon, his head crowned with the Seven Treasures of Heavenly Origin, clad in a cloud-light brocade skirt sewn with nine-colored pearls, girded with Six Mountain Fire Jade, and belted with the Purple Cord of Numinous Flight. He constantly stands upon a five-colored lion lotus, resplendent in the seventy-four directions of Highest Clarity. In the autumn months, his form changes—a human head upon a tiger’s body, adorned with dark and yellow patterns, his radiant cloud-light illuminating a thousand directions. By the end of the third month, his form changes again—his entire body golden, his head bearing a floral canopy, clad in a thirty-two-colored Dharma robe, like the image of the Buddha, his luminosity brilliant, illuminating Highest Clarity.")*

In the spring months, his form transforms into a tri-colored radiance of purple, yellow, and green, intertwining and coiling, the Three Qi merging in primordial chaos within the realm of Highest Clarity. The Vast Luminance Purple Orchid Middle Origin Lofty Maiden, her stature spanning thirty million *zhang*. In the autumn months, her head crowned with a Three-Flowered Treasure Diadem, clad in a seven-colored robe of divine essence, girded with a flowing gold purple sash, and bearing a stone-essence sword of golden light, she ever stands upon azure mist, her seven-colored tiger chariot resplendent in thirty-two hues of luminosity.

In the winter months, her form changes—a tiger’s body with a dragon’s head, adorned with five-colored patterns, her brilliance radiant amidst the azure clouds, upon a five-colored lotus. In the spring months, she transforms once more—three-headed phoenix, nine-colored patterns, her luminosity dazzling, illuminating Highest Clarity. In the summer months, her form shifts into a dual radiance of purple and azure, intertwining and coiling like the rising sun.

The *Scripture of the Supreme Perfection’s Regulations* states: At the dawn of creation, sagely perfected immortals all proclaimed the Dao and qi, established dharmic forms, and transmitted them to those of the same lineage. The Most High called them "scholars," for they took the Dao as their affair—hence, the "affair of the Dao." Through merit in the affair of the Dao, they were titled "Daoists." The Daoist takes the Dao as their affair, and through sagely destiny ascends and transcends.

When the multitude of demons arise, it is due to the shallowness of human sentiment. Though the perverse may assail the upright, when the true departs, the perverse arrive, mingling with perverse people yet never encroaching upon the upright. The upright who serve the Dao, study the dharma, and follow the regulations—how would demon kings dare disrespect them, or perverse spirits dare invade?

Thus, those who receive the Dao in body are all high officials of the heavenly demons, while the multitude of heavenly demon spirits are all subordinate officials to the Daoists.

The *Scripture of Ascending Mystery* states: The worthy and the vulgar differ in every affair. Their eyes do not wander, nor are they startled by beauty; their ears do not heed slander, nor listen to chaotic sounds; their noses do not accept fragrance, nor the stench of the sweet; their mouths do not taste delicacies, nor consume living beings; their hearts do not crave wealth, beauty, or fleeting glory; their hands do not act deceitfully; their feet do not tread evil paths. Such are the practices of the Daoist.

The *Scripture of the Great Vows and Precepts* states: The man of the Dao takes from his own body and seeks nothing from others. The Dao says: Cultivate it in the self, and its virtue becomes true. This is the meaning.

The *Scripture of the Abyssal Cavern* states: Noble Daoists are all born from the heavens above. Without prior lives’ accumulation of goodness, one cannot become a Daoist.

The *Scripture of the Orthodox Unity Perfected One’s Exposition of the Thousand Illuminations* states: Daoists of pure virtue who have traversed the Three Vehicles, teach and transform all beings, perform myriad good deeds, and act in accordance with the dharma may advance to offer veneration to the Three Caverns’ sacred scriptures.

The *Scripture of the Supreme Perfection’s Numinous Writ of the Great Empyrean* states: Understanding must be single-minded; single-mindedness must yield response; response then communicates with the divine—why labor over invocation? Joy and sorrow both abandoned, day and night diligently devoted, vowing to advance without retreat—this is called a "man of the Dao." One who practices the Great Dao is called a "Daoist." What is a *shi* (士)? It is *li* (理, principle) and *shi* (事, affair). Body and mind follow principle, adhering only to the Dao, taking the Dao as their affair—hence the title "Daoist."

The *Master’s Scripture on the Dignified Rituals of the Chamber of Instruction* states: The Perfected One said: If a scholar can cast off worldly burdens and aspire to wander among mountains and waters, upholding the Wheel of the Supreme Dharma, they are called a *Master*, ever seated upon a high dais reciting scriptures, teaching and transforming the foolish and the wise, opening the path for all learners. If further possessed of pure perfection and utmost virtue, able to penetrate the mysteries of the abstruse, their disciples and fellow students may address them as "Master So-and-So." Those who plumb the depths and reach the far, whose talent and learning are profoundly mysterious, whose aspirations lie in the Great Vehicle—these may be called *Master of Mystic Stillness*, or *Master of Wandering the Mysteries*, or *Master of Distant Wandering*, or *Master of Proclaiming the Dao*, or *Master of Expounding the Mysteries*. To list them all would be inexhaustible; when the world has such persons, they are called *Master Daoists*.

The *Scripture of Ascending Mystery* states: The Immortal Duke again knelt before the Perfected One of the Great Ultimate and said: "I sincerely beseech the Master to bestow the grace of the dharma, to moisten the withered and parched, that future Daoists may cultivate utmost perfection and abandon perverse arts."

The *Scripture of the Three Primes’ Distribution* states: The Supreme Perfection Lord of the Great Dao received this scripture from the Master of Primordial Antiquity and transmitted it to the Immortal King of the Mystic Capital.

The *Scripture of the Seventy-Four Methods of Transfiguration of the Supreme Clarity* states: The Master of the Purple Palace can achieve immortality, serene and harmonious with heaven’s truth, contemplating deeply and guarding the spirit. Though he has lived three thousand years, he has not yet ascended to heaven, lingering in the cavern chamber to select and await the perfected.

The *Scripture of the Primordial Beginning’s Transfiguration of Mount Tortoise’s Primordial Record* states: The Venerable Master of the Myriad Beginnings bears a form inscribed with ninety million patterns. In the three winter months, his head is crowned with a diadem of cinnabar sunlight, he wears a robe of red cloud luminous brocade, girded with a sash of golden tiger and phoenix patterns, and a purple seal of the cinnabar emperor. Ever riding white clouds, seated upon a five-colored lion, his radiance flows and shines, illuminating Supreme Clarity. In the three spring months, he transforms into a three-headed phoenix, clad in a nine-colored tiger robe of mottled patterns, ever standing upon twelve luminous flowers. In the three summer months, he shifts into the radiance of three suns, eight rays of purple light blazing and resplendent, above Supreme Clarity amidst twelve-colored lotuses. In the three autumn months, he assumes the form of intertwining lights of azure, red, and purple, coiling like the sun’s wheel.

The *Scripture of the Purple Dawn of Supreme Clarity* states: The Venerable Master of the Supreme Sovereign, the Purple Dawn Lord, is the offspring of the Two Radiant Ones, born of the essence of Jade Dawn within the Dragon Mist of the Great Void. Enveloping the Purple Emptiness to commune with the numinous, entrusting the Nine Mysteries to contain his brilliance, he congealed the vast dew to form his spirit. Refining the Three Qi to contemplate himself, passing through the Mystic Mother to be dharma-born, he endured kalpas of transformation, moved by auspicious days to manifest his form. Thus, in the first year of the Supreme Sovereign, the Heavenly Stem Jia inaugurated the dawn, and he was born in the Heaven of Eight Clarities of the Divine Continent, in the central domain of the Level Mound, by the shore of the Abyssal Cavern. At birth, his face shone with golden countenance, his body radiated jade light, adorned with five-colored purple patterns, capable of seventy-two transformations. His jade-like visage was refined, divine dragons spat mushrooms to bathe him, simurghs and phoenixes spread their wings to shade the mysterious. Cinnabar clouds scattered their splendor upon his jasper pavilion, flowing light blazed upon the radiant perfected. The Two Radiant Ones paused their brilliance in the Eight Mysteries, the Seven Primes revolved their essence to assist the dawn. Golden immortals scattered incense to mingle with the qi, divine consorts cast flowers to emit mist. The Five Wefts wove their patterns into the numinous splendor of the Purple Heaven. At the age of eighteen, he roamed the Middle Prime, ingesting essence and swallowing qi, exhaling and inhaling numinous fluids, containing mushrooms to inwardly irrigate, congealing his spirit into an embryonic immortal. Drawing in and rinsing, guarding silence, serene and natural, his thoughts subtle and his qi unceasing, he accumulated resonance with the Cavern Prime. His name transcended Supreme Clarity, he received the title of Primordial Sovereign, and ascended to the Purple Dawn. Orchid winds responded to his emergence, following the flow of destiny. His spirit held the Five Luminaries, his form encompassed the Three Primes. Soaring through the empyrean, his chariot returned through mist, the multitude of immortals opened the path where three ways converged in brightness. Lightning flashed forth its might, his swift chariot traversed the Nine Mysteries. Twice he ascended the jade steps, thrice he paid homage in the Purple Court, gazing upon the jasper towers, feasting in the splendor of the Three Primes, forging bonds with the Five Elders. A guest of the Jade Empyrean, flying beasts raised their sleeves, divine phoenixes sang in accompaniment, mighty dragons guided his reins, spirit winds scattered incense, wafting fragrance in surging waves. The jade purity of the Supreme Clarity flourished, golden lads grasped the clouds to attend his wheels, jade maidens trod the void to guard his spirit.

The *Scripture of the Ink Records of the Supreme Cinnabar Tablets* states: Should one receive the dharma rank of Perfected Unity or the title of the Primordial One’s Unadorned Contract, one may be designated as a "Master." Those born under the eastern constellations shall be titled "Master of the Eastern Marchmount"; those born under the southern constellations, "Master of the Southern Marchmount"; those born under the western constellations, "Master of the Western Marchmount"; those born under the northern constellations, "Master of the Northern Tree"; and those born under the central seven constellations—Chen, Xu, Chou, Wei, and the Center—shall be titled "Master of the Central Marchmount." These Five Marchmount Masters first enter the Earthly Registers, possessing the virtue worthy of such designation. Without numinous resonance and spiritual response, one cannot be so titled without merit.

The *Inner Transmission of the Supreme Perfected* states: When one’s name enters the Supreme Mysterious Register, the demonic gods of the Three Realms and the spirits of the departed all revere them, calling them "Celestial Superior." Daoists should always remain humble, for no attainment surpasses this in purity and nobility. These are the oral instructions of Master Yin, transmitted to teach the worthy and sagely of the world.

The *Scripture of the Difficulties Among the Sages* records: The Immortal asked the Immortal Duke, "Previously, when you and the Superior entered Dongting to view the Heavenly King’s detached palace, upon first ascending Baoshan, we saw a group of immortals seeking to follow the Superior to observe the spectacle. What manner of immortals were they, that there were so many?" The Duke replied, "Those immortals are all from the grotto-chambers of the famous mountains. Yet they are not numerous—have you not seen the countless immortals of Kunlun, Penglai, Zhongshan, Songgao, Sumeru, and Lingwu, among the great mountain grotto-chambers?"

The *Scripture of the Immortal Duke’s Inquiries* states: The Demon King submits to the Supreme Perfected, the Celestial Worthies, and the Heavenly Superior.

The *Scripture of the Supreme Jade Pivot of the Grand Empyrean* states: The Superior and the wondrous adept harmonize their light with the dust, blunting sharpness and resolving strife. Though they dwell among the common, their secrets differ. They bear the registers and taboo names, inhaling primordial essence, establishing virtue and merit—beyond the ken of the ordinary.

The *Supreme Scripture of the Limitless Salvation of Numinous Treasure* states: The devoted scholar who recites the scripture ten times delivers those on the verge of death, reviving the perishing.

The *Scripture of the Dharma Wheel* states: I observe that the devoted scholar does not embrace worldly attachments.

The *Scripture of the Eightfold Simplicity of the Perfected* states: The numinous writ is solemn and weighty—one dare not hoard it, nor dare one transmit it lightly. If bound by yearly limits, eons may pass, and for the devoted scholar, the opportunity may never arise, leaving only sighs of thwarted aspiration. Though diligent, they achieve nothing, for the Primordial Beginning’s revelation is rarely met. Only when encounter aligns with the profound statutes of the Mysterious Code is it fitting to bestow.

The *Poor Daoist* in the *Instructions on the Numinous Unity of the Numinous Treasure* states: Those who seek the Dao of immortality must accumulate merit without limit, for when merit is complete, the Dao is naturally attained. The pursuit of the Dao is like a worldly person’s worry over poverty—none who persist fail to attain immortality. Thus, the Poor Daoist strives ceaselessly, devoted solely to the Dao, ever contending with the heart to subdue the illusions of demonic splendor. The term "Poor Daoist" is a general appellation for Shangqing Daoists.

The *Scripture of Resolute Will* records: A southern mountain Daoist answered Le Fa Xie, saying, "Last night, after descending from the lecture, I dreamed a man presented me with a true treasure—a ruyi scepter—and gave it to you. You accepted it, and I pondered, deeming it an auspicious omen."

The *Scripture of the Supreme Jade Pivot of the Grand Empyrean* states: Daoists, in humble acknowledgment of their incomplete mastery of the Dao, call themselves "Poor Daoists," or "Poor Scholars." Their understanding is not yet complete, and they feel as though something is lacking—hence the name "Poor Scholar." The scholar’s duty is to cultivate goodness as their vocation.

The *Master* in the *Scripture of the Great Precepts of Original Vows* records: The Supreme Ultimate Perfected answered the High Mystery Perfected, saying, "I am unworthy of the teaching and transformation, ashamed to be counted among the great masters." Here, "Master" refers to the Venerable Lord Ge. The Supreme has commanded—how dare I not pour forth all I possess?

The *Scripture of the Supreme Perfected’s Codes* states: The sagely master, moved by compassion, elucidates the scriptural codes, verifying them through precedent, resolving doubts and dispelling confusion, rectifying the perverse and aiding the upright, so that black and white are clearly distinguished.

The *Scripture of the Mysterious Teachings of the Yellow Emperor and Laozi* states: Among virtues, there are those who know and those who do not. The Dao exalts the latter. The inferior all claim knowledge as true knowledge, imitating one another in the world, yet none recognize that true knowing lies in not-knowing. This is the profound mastery of the Mysterious Artisan, ever abiding in unknowing.

The *Scripture of Great Peace* states: The bond between master and disciple is of immense weight, akin to that of parent and child—one cannot shirk or sever it. Those who are born and do not serve a worthy master, or who serve a foolish one, are taught evil and led into depravity, causing others to perish in body and soul. Their remaining sins may even consume their entire household. Some are born without seeking learning and thus become fools. The ignorant suffer alone, and in the underworld, their souls find no joy. Upon death, they do not become benevolent spirits. Now, the worthy master teaches people, transforming the most foolish into good; if goodness does not cease, they become virtuous; if virtue does not cease, they attain sageliness; if sageliness does not cease, they comprehend the true Dao; if they guard the Dao without ceasing, they become immortal and deathless; if immortality does not cease, they attain perfection; if perfection does not cease, they become divine; if divinity does not cease, they equal Heaven; if equality with Heaven does not cease, they equal the Primordial Qi; when they equal the Primordial Qi, they envelop Heaven and Earth, and the eight directions all receive their qi to live. Their virtue then blankets Heaven and Earth and the eight directions. Their spirit merges with Heaven and Earth, and all under Heaven partake of their sustenance, offering sacrifices in awe, fearing they cannot fully honor them. Such is the merit of the most worthy master and the good disciple.

It is further said: As a disciple, one should be reverent and attentive from dawn to dusk, following the master’s teachings without the slightest deviation. One must not speak recklessly to disrupt the master’s goings and comings, nor cause the master worry. From the moment one receives instruction, one must not transgress, utter no harsh words, and never oppose the master’s will—such is the most excellent disciple.

Master Yi Zhen’s words approach this standard, yet they do not qualify as the most excellent disciple, but only as a middling one. Nevertheless, the most excellent disciple, after receiving the master’s teachings, bears in mind the master’s grace, thereby attaining full personhood. They then accompany worthy immortals without fail, never straying from their ranks. Some may obtain official positions to repay their parents, while others may delve deeply into the Dao, mastering the art of self-nourishment.

Having been born of parents, perfected their virtue through the master, and honored their lord with glory, when dwelling alone, they reflect upon the aging of their lord, father, and master, realizing there is nothing with which to repay them. They constantly yearn to obtain rare methods and extraordinary texts to requite their master’s merit, and in their remorse, their hearts ache with sorrow. Thus, they further study and serve the worthy, entrusting their master to them, speaking on their behalf, enabling the master to become a fine minister to the state and benefit the ruler’s governance—such is the good disciple of ancient times.

The *Scripture of the Great Precepts of the Numinous Treasure* states: "Receive my Ten Precepts, practice the Twelve Permissibles, and by adhering to them, become a pure and faithful disciple of the Great Dao. In this present life, you may be freed from sorrow and distress, cross over all suffering, enter into radiant light, and purify your form within. You may summon ghosts and command spirits, subduing demonic forces."

It further says: "Those who have not yet attained the Dao but can fly through the heavens are the ten-turn disciples of the Dao. They soar through the void, driving the chariots of the various heavens. After ten turns, they may ascend to become flying immortals. If, in their first turn, they practice with diligence, their hearts unwavering, performing meritorious deeds, observing strict fasts and austerities from dawn to dusk without fatigue, they may attain the rank of flying immortal. From this, they may advance further, transcending the Three Realms to become Perfected Ones of the Upper Clarity."

The *True Scripture of the Eightfold Simplicity* states: "Those who follow the Three Luminaries and are called disciples of the Three Realms, having delivered three persons and entrusted them to their master and friends, may thereafter transmit the teachings and be called Masters of the Three Luminaries, Preceptors, and Perfected Ones, as designated by their master and recommended by their peers. Without having undergone formal petition and approval, they may not presumptuously claim such titles."

**Release by Means of the Corpse**
The *Scripture of the Chapters on the Generation of Spirits in the Nine Heavens* states: "Those who study the supreme Dao and aspire to immortality, having attained release by means of the corpse, pass through transformation and transference, ultimately returning to the immortal Dao. Their form and spirit unite, never parting, and together they enter the perfection of the Dao."

The *Scripture of the Regulations of the Illuminated Perfected* states: "Those born in the world who love learning, cultivate the scriptural teachings, ingest essence and swallow qi without ceasing, observe fasts and regulate their diet, refine themselves through breath control, accumulate merit and spread virtue—whose names are recorded in the Upper Clarity—may attain release by means of the corpse as lesser immortals, roaming the Five Marchmounts. Later, reborn among humans, they receive the scriptures and methods anew, becoming masters and exemplars. When their Dao is complete through cyclic cultivation, they attain the rank of superior immortals, ascending in broad daylight to positions of high nobility."

The *Scripture of the Golden Tablet and Jade Characters of the Grand Tenuity* states: "All those who preside over the subterranean realms of release by means of the corpse, according to the statutes of the Four Poles of the Perfected, must wait one hundred and forty years before being appointed to immortal offices. Only then may they ascend with flowered canopies, riding a host of dragons, to the Grand Ultimate and wander the Nine Palaces."

The *Upper Scripture of the Flying Immortal’s Precious Sword* states: "Release by means of the corpse is the transformation of the corporeal form, the refinement and shedding of the original true self, the wandering change of the bodily frame, the hidden departure of the five constituents. Though it ranks among the lower grades of immortality, the endowment and transmission one receives are not necessarily slight. Some may not yet wish to ascend to heaven but prefer to dwell in famous mountains; others may wish to exalt the teachings of the world, severing the path of life and death, cutting off the attachments of descendants, and making the pursuit of immortality their ultimate aspiration. Some may wish to observe the transformations of the world for long ages, dreading the toil of immortal offices. Once the wondrous Dao is complete, their rank and position are fitting, and one cannot use the clarity of life and death to fix their definitive status. These are what are called those who conceal the three luminaries and cause the sun to sink into the land."

It further states: "By applying the Elixir of the Recorded Form to fire and charcoal, others will see one’s form burned to death—this is called *fire release by means of the corpse*. By taking one pill with water, embracing a tree and lying down, others will see one wounded to death in an empty chamber—this is called *weapon release by means of the corpse*. In all cases, one may freely return to one’s hometown, though one must change one’s name and alter one’s appearance. In the past, there was one who practiced this method, entered Mount Linlü for thirteen years, and then returned home.

Those who undergo the lesser release by means of the corpse may not look back upon their hometowns. This is the way of the superior release, and their names are matched to the Purple Tablets of the Three Offices. They may not again peer into the gaps of the world, falsely imposing death upon themselves. Some die and revive, some are decapitated and die only to emerge from another side, some die and their corpses vanish before encoffining, some retain their human form but are without bones, some leave their clothes behind while their form departs, and some lose their hair and vanish. Those who depart in broad daylight are called *superior release by means of the corpse*; those who depart at midnight are called *inferior release by means of the corpse*; and those who depart at dawn or dusk are called *subterranean presiders*.

Though their traces and signs do not vanish, arousing human suspicion, and though they attain concealment, the world’s records remain unsatisfied, they may not return to their hometowns, and their wanderings lack stability.

**Subterranean Presiders**
The *Upper Scripture of the Flying Immortal’s Precious Sword* states: "Those of utmost loyalty and filial piety, upon death, all receive records to become subterranean presiders. After one hundred and forty years, they may receive the teachings of lesser immortals, gradually advancing in the Great Dao to be appointed to immortal offices. Every one hundred and forty years, they are permitted one trial for promotion."

Those of utmost filial piety can move ghosts and spirits, causing the birds of the mountains and beasts of the wild to flee from their graves. Those of utmost loyalty possess a forthright and unyielding heart, their essence piercing the bright sun; some split open their bowels or sacrifice their lives to rouse their lords.

Those endowed with the virtue of the highest sages, upon death, all receive records from the Three Offices to become subterranean presiders. After one thousand years, they may be promoted to the Five Emperors of the Three Offices or become the Illustrious Lords of the East, West, South, or North, governing ghosts and spirits. After another one thousand four hundred years, they may roam the Grand Clarity and become Central Immortals of the Nine Palaces.

Those possessing transcendent talent, surpassing the multitudes in renown, who nurture their vast integrity and seek no glory or rank, upon death receive records from the Three Offices to become *shanshuang* ghosts. After four hundred years, they may become subterranean presiders, advancing thereafter in stages of three hundred years each.

Those of utmost integrity and purity, upon death, receive records from the Three Offices to become *qing* ghosts. After two hundred eighty years, they may become subterranean presiders, gradually advancing to immortal offices in stages of two hundred eighty years each. Those of utmost integrity consume no food not their own, nor wear cloth not their own. Those of utmost purity cannot be swayed by splendor from their upright *qi*, nor can the might of ten thousand chariots shake their moral resolve.

If one’s ancestors rendered service to the Three Offices, the merit extends to their descendants, who may undergo refinement and transformation across generations, changing their surnames and being reborn. This is the seven-generation hidden virtue, its roots passing down in succession. Upon death, they leave behind a foot bone to return to the Three Offices, while the rest of their bones ascend with the body. Men leave the left bone, women the right, and all receive records to become subterranean presiders. After two hundred eighty years, they may advance to receive the Way of Earthly Immortals.

On the day of their passing, their form appears as flesh of the living. At the moment of death, their corpse does not stiffen, their toes do not turn blue, and the skin of their hands does not wrinkle—these are signs of one who, by prior virtue and conduct, naturally attains *release by means of the corpse*.

*Treatise on the Daoist Canon, Scroll Two* (conclusion)
*Treatise on the Daoist Canon, Scroll Three*

Slander

*The Hidden Writ of the Supreme Clarity’s Dragon Script* states: People are often false and shallow, failing to comprehend the ultimate principle. Their sins run deep, and their doubts obscure what is true and correct. Should they chance to hear subtle wonders, they respond with slander, treating them with disdain and disbelief, thereby falling into evil destinies. There, they endure the torments of wind and blade, suffering without respite across kalpas.

*The Scripture of Ascending Mystery* states: The Most High said: Those who slander this scripture shall, upon death, enter hell, endure the Three Offices’ interrogations, and in this life suffer from leprosy.

It further states: Dou Ziming said: The people of this world are deluded, driven by greed and self-indulgence. They fail to recognize the ultimate truth, resorting to flattery, deceit, and malice. Some envy the worthy and resent the capable, slandering and defaming one another. Others engage in lustful disputes, secretly cursing and harming others. Some rely on strength and power to bully the weak. Some insist on their own rightness while dismissing others. Some perform minor good deeds but, after mere days or months without sincere devotion, demand immediate results. When their desires go unmet, they dismiss the teachings of past lives and karma, claiming there is no retribution. This is like a farmer planting grain—spring planting yields autumn harvest. To sow and then demand immediate cooking would be to starve. Cultivating blessings and performing good deeds is the same: blessings accumulate into fortune, while misdeeds accumulate into calamity. This is as clear as daylight, yet people refuse to believe—how lamentable!

Defamation

*The Statutes of Illuminating Perfection* states: In the boundless world, men and women who live in defiance of the Dao criticize and defame the celestial perfected, disbelieve in scriptures and precepts, speak falsely while harboring deceit, and secretly plot evil. Their sins are grave, and upon death, they endure bitter torments. Even if they return to the human realm, they are reborn among border barbarians, no longer of the human kind, destined to suffer the consequences of a hundred evils in repayment for past transgressions. Forever severed from the human path, they have no return, drifting endlessly through the gates of sin, their births and deaths unknown.

Assault

*The Statutes of Illuminating Perfection* states: In the boundless world, men and women who, in their conduct, scrutinize and attack the four ranks of beings, assaulting celestial immortals, shall upon death endure cruel retribution, forever mired in evil roots.

*The Scripture of Ascending Mystery* states: The Dao says: Those who, in their allotted lifespan, reject scriptural teachings, disparage divine immortals, indulge their reckless impulses, kill and punish beyond measure, curse heaven and earth, and attack perfected beings—such deeds are reported by the hosts of the Mysterious Bureau to the vast heavens. I shall then command the Director of Destinies to consign them to Fengdu, cutting short their predetermined lifespan. If they persist in their ways without repentance, their lineage will be severed, and ancestral sacrifices will cease.

*The Scripture of the Dharma Wheel* states: The Dao says: I have surveyed the heavens and seen that among the people of this world, men and women who uproot their foundations, attack their superiors, slander and strike the worthy, flatter and harm the loyal, and take lives—such souls cry out endlessly in death. Their sins are grave, and they incur present retributions of manifold suffering, enduring through ten thousand kalpas. They shall be reborn in barbarian lands, possessing human form but lacking human nature.

Indulgence in Wine

*The Most High’s Scripture on Wisdom and Dispelling Demons* states: The Most High said: Wine is the essence of grains and water, capable of circulating qi and fluids. In moderation, it aids the spirit and benefits nature; in excess, it disrupts the spirit and harms life. To indulge to the point of death is not the way of wisdom.

*The Scripture of Alliance and Might* states: The Most High said: The talented and wise are obsessed with wine, their faces flushed and minds clouded, their natures inverted. They destroy the ten virtues and foster the ten evils, blocking the four directions and obstructing the six penetrations. They must swiftly abandon it.

*The Scripture of Lord Lao’s Statutes and Decrees* states: The noble drink wine to celebrate; the base drink to provoke strife. There are twenty-four matters clearly outlined—those who uphold goodness must observe them. To violate even one is to fail as a disciple.

1. When drunk, subjects disrespect their lords, and lords may grow arrogant and violent. Wives defy their husbands, and children disobey their fathers.
2. Drunkenness leads to the loss of virtue, and wanton behavior knows no bounds.
3. When drunk, words flow recklessly, speech becomes insolent, and respect for hierarchy vanishes.
4. When drunk, one cannot sit still, swaying and stumbling.
5. When drunk, one soils the bed with vomit and filth.
6. When drunk, one loses all fear, imagining they can strike a tiger or leap into fire or water.
7. When drunk, one reveals others’ private affairs.
8. When drunk, one speaks carelessly, without restraint or fear.
9. When drunk, one lies like the dead, utterly senseless.
10. When drunk and returning home, even family flees, fearing them as they would a tiger or bandit.
11. Drunkenness may cause illness, leaving the face sallow and yellow.
12. When drunk, one may lie alone on the road, losing all possessions.
13. Drunkenness leads to squandering family wealth on wine, resulting in poverty.
14. When drunk, one may curse the gods, tear off clothes, and run wildly, fighting with anyone encountered.
15. When drunk, one may steal without regard for kinship.
16. When drunk, one fails to distinguish good from evil.
17. When drunk, one may destroy household items.
18. When drunk, one neglects family affairs and forgets wife and children.
19. When drunk, one neglects official duties, leading to demotion.
20. Drunkenness may bring disaster, or in the case of generals, lead to military defeat.
21. When drunk, one may fall from a horse, injuring the face.
22. When drunk, one becomes confused, neglecting work, fields, and silkworms.
23. Prolonged drunkenness rots the intestines and stomach, harming life.
24. Drunkenness harms the spirit, disrupts qi, damages virtue, and corrupts the true nature. Beware of it!

*The Statutes of Illuminating Perfection* states: In the boundless world, men and women who, in their conduct, indulge in wine and lust, lose their nature in confusion and madness, their five emotions in chaos, their spirits scattered, and their qi depleted. Drunkenness leads to desire, and they commit evil unknowingly, shouting curses, acting alone without restraint, striking the good, defiling and disrespecting the Dao and its teachings, slandering scriptures, turning from truth to falsehood, breaking promises, deceiving the four ranks of beings, and straying from the Way. Their sins are deeply perverse. Upon death, they endure severe retribution, their souls suffering intensely, dragged through the dark waves of the Four Rivers, condemned to labor in the Yangtze and Yellow River, toiling day and night without rest. Shackled in iron chains, they are dragged endlessly through the eternal night, never to escape across ten thousand kalpas. They shall be reborn among the lowly, poor, and diseased, despised by all in repayment for past enmity. The path of blessings grows ever distant, while the roots of sin entangle deeper, leaving no way to liberation or escape.

The *Hymn of the Flying Celestials* states:
Loving wine, they lose their fundamental conduct,
The Five Spirits all run wild in madness.
Upon death, they draw the dark waves’ water,
To pour and drench the Four Rivers’ depths.

The *Sutra of Retribution for Womb-Dwelling Karma* says:
There are those who superficially honor the Three Treasures,
Their faith unsteady, indulging in wanton dissipation,
Mired in lust and desire, they falsely invoke scriptures
To seek fame and profit, gathering crowds
And mingling in wrongdoing.
Such people, upon death, face severe trials in the Three Evil Realms,
Forever without release.

The *Scripture of the Great Precepts of the Numinous Treasure* says:
The Heavenly Worthy declares: Beware the unrestrained gaze of lust,
For the spirit of the eyes, unchecked, clings to desire.
Steady the pupils, contemplate true stillness,
That wisdom may flow and the void be perceived.

**Lack of Compassion**
The *Scripture of Illuminating Truth* states:
In the boundless world, men and women in life
Act without kindness or benevolence,
Boiling and slaughtering the six livestock,
Carving and maiming, cutting short beasts’ lives,
Poisoning and butchering sentient beings.
Their sins are deeply perverse; upon death, they endure cruel retribution—
Swallowing fire, eating coals, burned by flames,
Their faces scorched, their bodies rotting,
No longer human in form.
They bear iron staves, wear mountains of fire,
Pain beyond endurance, torment beyond bearing,
No liberation possible—how may they return?

The *Lament of the Flying Celestials* says:
Failing to cherish a heart of compassion,
Cruelly harming living beings,
Their souls, in death, bear iron staves,
For ten thousand kalpas wear mountains of fire.

**Lack of Filial Piety**
The *Scripture of Illuminating Truth* states:
In the boundless world, men and women in life
Are unfilial, cursing and humiliating parents,
Relatives turning against one another.
Their sins are deeply perverse; upon death, they endure cruel retribution.
For ten thousand kalpas, they are reborn among the six livestock,
At the mercy of others’ slaughter, repaying past enmity.
Forever losing the human path, they sink into evil roots.

**The Three Obstructions**
The *Sutra of the Primordial Lord’s Wisdom and Right Contemplation for Liberation* states:
The Dao Lord should know that from the Three Poisons arise the Three Obstructions.
First, afflictions.
Second, karmic deeds.
Third, retribution.
Due to these Three Obstructions, practitioners cannot attain true cultivation of right contemplation.
Afflictions refer to love and delusion constantly dwelling in the heart,
Preventing the arising of right understanding.
Laboring in attachment is called the obstruction of afflictions.
The obstruction of karma arises from desiring to perform good deeds,
While evil deeds weigh heavily, inevitably yielding worldly fruits of suffering and joy.
One cannot cultivate practices that transcend the world,
Thus blocking right wisdom—this is called the obstruction of karma.
The obstruction of retribution means rebirth in the Three Evil Realms,
Where suffering torments the body, leaving no means to cultivate precepts and wisdom.
Those in the heavens and among humans cling to pleasure,
Failing to awaken to impermanence.
Desire veils them, never ceasing day or night.
Poverty, distress, and illness—all conditions unmet—
Prevent the cultivation of the right path to transcend the world.
This is called the obstruction of retribution.
Those of wisdom, recognizing this,
Should skillfully transform these obstructive dharmas.

**The Three Fears**
The *Scripture of Ascending Mystery* states:
The Most High said: Dao Ling, know that in the latter age, the people have three things to fear. Examine them well.
First, jealousy of the Dao and its teachings is to be feared.
Second, slander is to be feared.
Third, greed and desire are to be feared.
Jealousy of the Dao and its teachings prevents the scriptures from spreading.
Slandering Dharma masters causes the people’s faith to waver.
Greed for wealth and sensuality makes one despised.
Of these three, two lie without, one within.
Only by removing these three afflictions can the Dao be transmitted.
Encourage and uphold its study.
The Most High then composed a song:
Jealousy of those better than oneself,
Slander of the wise and enlightened,
Greed and lust for wealth and sensuality—
These prevent the transmission of my scriptures.
While these three afflictions remain,
How can one hope for the unseen realms?
False conduct seeks profit and sustenance,
Never possessing true sincerity.
Seeing others honor virtue,
The heart clings to malice.
Such people are detested by spirits,
In life, they earn a foul name.
Upon death, they descend to the dark realms,
Suffering trials in the ghostly prisons.
Through countless kalpas, they revolve in the wheel,
Enduring countless forms of punishment.

**The Three Poisons**
The *Sutra of the Primordial Lord’s Wisdom and Right Contemplation for Liberation* states:
The Most High Dao Lord addressed the Heavenly Worthy:
What are the characteristics of afflictions?
The Heavenly Worthy replied: Afflictions are collectively called the Three Poisons—greed, hatred, and delusion.
They harm the Dharma-body and life of sentient beings, hence they are called poisons.
Greed means insatiable grasping,
Clinging to desire and attachment without end.
Seeking pleasure in worldly and transcendent dharmas—
All this is called greed.
Hatred means harboring resentment and rage toward sentient beings and non-sentient things,
Fierce anger blazing like fire,
Burning away good roots, binding deep enmity—
This is called hatred.
Delusion means lacking faith in and understanding of the Three Treasures and the true Dharma,
Arrogant, deceitful, and crooked, knowing nothing,
Bumping into walls without foundation,
Refusing admonition, delighting in useless speech,
Committing many evil deeds, straying from the Way—
This is called ignorance.

**The Four Afflictions**
The *Scripture of Ascending Mystery* states:
The Most High said: Dao Ling, know that people of the world have four unwholesome dharmas, most difficult to remove—the gravest illnesses of the Dao. You should recognize them. What are the four?
First, worldly people do not seek the guidance of those with the Dao, and they are ashamed to ask their inferiors.
Second, though they have practiced the Dao for a long time, their knowledge and insight remain shallow. Seeing those superior to themselves, they are ashamed to learn further.

Third, claiming vast learning, they refuse to heed other scriptures.
Fourth, they belittle later learners, saying they know nothing.
Such four kinds of people, though they study the Dao, labor in vain!
They cannot attain the Dao, nor achieve any penetration—no spiritual verification comes to them. Why toil in vain?
From the outset, such people seek the Dao without wholehearted sincerity, desiring only fame and offerings.
Ever devouring fire and poison as food, they take others’ wealth for clothing—like swords and spears piercing their bodies.
Coveting immediate gain, they know not the profound calamities awaiting them in later lives.
Upon death, they enter hell, where molten iron and boiling bronze are poured into their mouths, and iron needles and thorns are fashioned into garments to clothe their bodies.
Beaten and flogged without respite, day and night, for countless kalpas, they may at last be reborn as humans—only to dwell in lowly stations, as slaves, servants, soldiers, or menial laborers.
Though the worthies teach and expound the scriptures, they are barred from hearing them. Even if they wish to learn anew, they cannot act freely.
Even now, I see before me such multitudes—beyond counting—most pitiable indeed!
Let the enlightened teachings be passed on to come: be vigilant! Be vigilant!

The Five Desires
The *Scriptural Teachings of Lord Lao* states: Greed and desire are boundless. From these boundless desires, thoughts arise in endless succession, beyond all reckoning. In broad terms, there are five:

First, the eyes crave the sight of the five colors—when colors exceed measure, the *hun*-soul is wearied.
Second, the ears crave the sound of the five tones—when tones grow clamorous, the *po*-soul suffers.
Third, the nose craves the scent of the five fragrances—when fragrances overflow, essence flows away.
Fourth, the mouth craves the sweetness of the five flavors—when flavors abound, the spirit grows turbid.
Fifth, the body craves indulgence in the five limbs—when the limbs grow sluggish, the will scatters.

When the will scatters, the spleen is harmed, and conduct becomes perilous.
When the spirit grows turbid, the heart is disordered, and the mouth errs.
When essence flows away, the kidneys are depleted, and madness ensues.
When the *po*-soul suffers, the lungs are damaged, and the ears grow deaf.
When the *hun*-soul is wearied, the liver is afflicted, and the eyes dim.

When these five are muddled and obscured, the body perishes and life ends.
When these five are pure, the body remains whole and years endure.

The Five Turbidities
Now an explanation: First, the turbidity of life; second, the turbidity of views; third, the turbidity of affliction; fourth, the turbidity of birth; fifth, the turbidity of the age.

The *Scripture of the Jade Key of Numinous Treasure* states: The Supreme Dao Lord addressed Wang Longci, a diligent scholar of the Dao, saying: "I received the ancient scriptures from the Primordial Beginning Perfected One. I expound the present by citing the past, and verify the present by invoking the past—this is deeply trustworthy. After ten thousand kalpas, the Dao will return to the Supreme Wanning-Li Heaven. Thereafter, in the midst of the Five Turbidities, I now explain their time and place.

To encounter misfortune in life—this is the turbidity of life. Not only are the years few and life cut short, but past karma is also impure. Whether man or woman, they do not behold the scriptural teachings and constantly dwell in evil destinies.

This is the turbidity of views: perverse views cloud the heart, and the true principle is not believed. The sin of slandering the Dharma is grave, and one lingers long in hell. Life is brief, yet sorrow and affliction cling to oneself. One suffers many unjust hardships—this is the turbidity of affliction. Greed, wrath, and delusion may give rise to fear and dread, entangling those who cultivate the Dao.

Born only to die, one revolves through the five paths, falling into the three wretched destinies and the eight difficulties—this is the turbidity of birth. Submitting to fate’s rise and fall, one revolves through suffering and hardship, obstructed from the true Dao. Karmic retribution drags one endlessly. In life and death, there is separation; no one, high or low, escapes—this is the turbidity of the age. As the great kalpa nears its end, all evil fruits ripen, and suffering is universally endured. Truly, this is grievous to the heart.

Now I explain these evils to deliver those who can be delivered. You must rectify your intent and attentively receive my words." Thereupon, the commentary was written.

Longci bowed his head and reverently received the teachings. Now, the Supreme One, moved by compassion, transmitted the scriptural key so that the obstructions of the Five Turbidities might dissolve, preserving the fortune of Great Peace.

The *Scripture of Bright Perfection’s Regulations* states: People of future ages, not beholding the regulations and precepts, will tread the poisonous broth of the Five Turbidities, encounter calamities and harm, and be unable to deliver themselves.

The *Scripture of the Numinous Book for Delivering Life* states: The Primordial Beginning Heavenly Worthy said: "After my passing, the true scriptures will be hidden away. The kalpa will grow short, the Five Turbidities will stir in contention, and myriad evils will converge. How lamentable that those born into such an age willingly tread the path of sin, revolving through the five paths, enduring the long suffering of the eight difficulties, harming one another, affliction clinging to the body. They do not behold the scriptures and do not encounter sacred texts, submitting to the rise and fall of fate in life and death. How pitiful indeed!"

The Seven Harms
